name: Hanoi Old Quarter
fun_fact: Fun fact: The Nguyen dynasty taxed buildings based on street frontage, leading Hanoians to build 'tube houses' - narrow facades (sometimes just 2-3 meters wide) that stretch deep and high with multiple courtyards, creating the Old Quarter's distinctive narrow architecture that survives 2,000 years later.

hero_dishes.name: Pho
hero_dishes.description: Aromatic beef or chicken broth poured over rice noodles, topped with thinly sliced meat, fresh herbs (Thai basil, cilantro, sawtooth coriander), lime, and chili
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in early 20th century Hanoi, possibly from French pot-au-feu influence during colonial rule. Street vendors balanced bamboo poles with pots of simmering broth, selling bowls at dawn. Hanoi pho is more subtle and refined than southern versions - fewer garnishes, clearer broth, focus on beef. Locals eat it for breakfast, slurping loudly to show appreciation.

hero_dishes.name: Bun Cha
hero_dishes.description: Grilled pork patties and pork belly served over rice vermicelli with dipping broth (n∆∞·ªõc ch·∫•m), fresh herbs, and pickled vegetables
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in Hanoi's Old Quarter in the 1950s, possibly on Gia Ngu Street near Hang Be Market. The first vendor grilled pork over charcoal, creating smoky patties dunked in sweet-sour-spicy broth. It became Obama and Anthony Bourdain's famous meal in 2016 at Bun Cha Huong Lien - now called the 'Obama bowl.' True Hanoians eat it only at lunch.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gia Ngu Street near Hang Be Market (original location, open 10:30AM-2:30PM), Bun Cha 74 Hang Quat (generous portions, secret marinade), Bun Cha Ta at 21 Nguyen Huu Huan (top ten street food), or Bun Cha Dac Kim (famous crab spring rolls)

hero_dishes.origin_story: French colonizers brought baguettes, Vietnamese added local ingredients. The perfect banh mi has a crispy crust from rice flour-wheat mix, airy inside from high humidity during baking. The filling balance is an art: rich p√¢t√©, savory meats, tangy pickles, fresh herbs, spicy chilies. Street carts assemble them to order in 30 seconds.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Old Quarter (look for charcoal grills and crowds), Banh Mi 25 on Hang Ca Street (tourist famous but good), or local carts near Dong Xuan Market

hero_dishes.name: Egg Coffee (C√† Ph√™ Tr·ª©ng)
hero_dishes.description: Vietnamese coffee topped with thick, creamy foam made from whipped egg yolk, sugar, and condensed milk - tastes like liquid tiramisu
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in 1946 at Giang Cafe when milk was scarce after French departure. Bartender Nguyen Van Giang whipped egg yolks with sugar and condensed milk to create foam topping for coffee. The original cafe still operates, run by his descendants. Drink it hot or iced, but always sip through the foam - never stir.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cafe Giang (original location since 1946), Cafe Dinh, or Hanoi Social Club

signature_drinks.name: Bia Hoi
signature_drinks.description: Fresh draft lager brewed daily, matured briefly, delivered by motorbike - the world's cheapest beer
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Hanoians gather at plastic tables on sidewalks (bia hoi corners) after work, drinking from small glasses while snacking on peanuts or grilled meats. The beer costs around 5,000-10,000 VND (20-40 cents USD). It's weak (3% alcohol) so locals drink many glasses. Peak time is 4-7PM. The beer is gone when the keg runs out.

food_culture_notes: Each street in the '36 Streets' historically specialized in one craft - Hang Bac (silver), Hang Gai (silk), Hang Tre (bamboo)
Street food timing matters: pho for breakfast (6-9AM), bun cha for lunch (11AM-2PM), bia hoi for evening (4-7PM)
Plastic stools and low tables are standard - squat down with locals, ignore the lack of amenities
Cash only at most stalls - meals cost $1-3 USD, look for busy stalls with high turnover for freshness

landmarks: Lake of the Restored Sword (Hoan Kiem Lake) with red bridge to Ngoc Son Temple
Dong Xuan Market - Vietnam's oldest and largest market since colonial times
Hang Bac Street - one of Vietnam's oldest streets, silver casting since 13th century
Train Street - railway line with Vietnamese-Korean street art murals between buildings
atmosphere: 2,000-year-old quarter evolving from snake-infested swamp to bustling craft guilds
Narrow 'tube houses' from dynasty-era frontage taxes
